Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Coding and Information Theory for Interactive Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project expands classical information and coding theories to the interactive communication settings. Information and coding theories give us a near-perfect understanding of the capacity of networks, such as the Internet or mobile networks, to transmit information. This understanding however, is generally limited to the non-interactive setting: there is a sender and a receiver and the goal is to transmit a message from the sender to the receiver as quickly and reliably as possible. In recent years, applications such as cloud computing gave rise to interactive communication problems, where the goal is to implement a whole functionality over a communication channel, rather than just transmit data. The investigators study fundamental questions surrounding extending information theory approaches to interactive problems. The project aims to establish the limits of interactive computation, as well as to develop new encoding algorithms that make interactive computing more efficient.

The key technical concept being developed by the investigators is that of information complexity. Information complexity is the natural generalization of Shannon's entropy to interactive problems. Shannon's entropy measures the amount of information contained in a random message. Interactive information complexity measures the amount of information contained in the interactive computation, as perceived by the participating parties. The project develops this concept to address problems in communication complexity, such as direct sum theorems, multi-party communication complexity, and hardness amplification. More broadly, the investigators develop techniques for applying information theory to computational complexity, with the aim of expanding the technical toolbox available to attack fundamental problems in complexity theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project encompassed a broad agenda around building an interactive analogue of classical information and coding theory, and expanding the role information theory plays in theoretical computer science and computational complexity theory.

Intellectual merit. Most of the original goals the project has set out to achieve have been accomplished. The accomplishments can be broadly classified into two categories: developing the theory of information complexity and developing interactive coding schemes.

On the information complexity theory side, in five years the project helped grow this field from a collection of nice theorems to an accomplished theory with connections to other areas such as quantum and distributed computing. Information complexity tools developed under the project allowed our team to obtain optimal results for old problems in complexity theory including the Direct Product theorem for communication complexity and the Parallel Repetition theorem. Our team has also studied basic properties of information complexity, answering questions such as “how much information do two players need to exchange to solve the two-bit AND function”, and “can the information complexity of a function be computed from its truth table”. In terms of connection-building, we have developed or expanded connections between information complexity and Algorithmic Game Theory (through the complexity of computing Nash Equilibria), Optimization (through the study of extended formulations), Quantum Information Theory, Statistical Learning Theory (through direct-sum techniques), and Distributed Computing (by various extensions of information complexity notions to multi-party scenarios).

On the interactive coding side, we have contributed to the development of optimally resilient good error-correcting interactive schemes in a variety of settings. Our biggest theoretical contribution in the two-terminal regime was constructing an interactive analogue of good list-decodable codes. List-decoding refers to a branch of coding theory where messages are affected by so much noise that it is impossible to uniquely recover the original message that has been sent – yet, constructions exist where one can always narrow the recovery down to a (short) list of potential original messages. The existence interactive list-decodable codes was a necessary block for achieving optimal error-resistance even in the standard communication model, where the parties want to uniquely recover their conversation that is being affected by noise. Follow-up work used tools developed in the list-decoding construction to tackle previously intractable communication models such as interactive channels with insertions and deletions. In the multi-terminal regime, we showed that the ability of parties to communicate in an interactive setting crucially depends on the topology of the network connecting them – by exhibiting both new upper and lower bounds.

Broader impact. A significant impact of this project was in providing professional development opportunities for the junior personnel involved in the project. Work under the project involved at least four postdocs, six graduate students, and about a dozen undergraduate project and thesis students. Two graduate students whose work was primarily on the scope of this project successfully graduated in 2015 and 2016, respectively, and secured prestigious postdoctoral positions. At least three of the undergraduate students continued to a PhD program in a top computer science program.

A number of cross-disciplinary dissemination events were undertaken under this project. These include a 2014 lecture at the high-profile International Congress of Mathematicians, a 2015 tutorial at the International Symposium on Information Theory, two tutorials at top theoretical computer science conferences (in 2013 and 2016), and a semester-long program on connections between information and computation theories at the Institut Henri Poincaré in Paris.
